data.title: MonoGame MacOS install not appearing in Xamarin Studio

The old plugin doesn't work with current version of Xamarin Studio (6.0.2b73 in my case), making it difficult to actually use MonoGame, or even tell that it was successfully installed. data.title: Added Localized Resource Processing and Loading.
data.body:
Fixes #5136

When localizing games you sometimes need to load localized
assets as well as text. This commit includes the sample
XNA processors and ContentManager code into the core of the
MonoGame system. This means that people no longer need to
implement this stuff themselves.

Usage:

Define all of the "string" resources in standard .resx resource
files. Add these to the .spritefont file

```
   <ResourceFiles>
      <Resx>..\Strings.resx</Resx>
      <Resx>..\Strings.da.resx</Resx>
      <Resx>..\Strings.fr.resx</Resx>
      <Resx>..\Strings.ja.resx</Resx>
      <Resx>..\Strings.ko.resx</Resx>
    </ResourceFiles>
```

Change the .spritefont over to use the LocalizedFontProcessor.
Load the font as normal.

For other localized assets you can make use of the new

``````
```Content.LoadLocalized<T>```
``````

method. This will attempt to load assets which contain a culture
extension e.g

```
Texture1.fr.xnb
Texture1.en-gb.xnb
```

Note either the Name or the TwoLetterISOLanguageName can be used.

data.title: DXT Compression: Keep the delegate from being re-located or collected…
data.body:
… by the garbage collector.

fix: http://community.monogame.net/t/mgcb-dxt-compression-sometimes-throws-nullpointer/7356
fix: http://community.monogame.net/t/upgrading-to-monogame-3-5-1-from-3-5-0-1122-processor-textureprocessor-had-an-unexpected-failure/7432

DXT code uses callbacks from unmanaged code. Under memory pressure those delegates could be re-located resulting to invalid pointers in nvtt.dll. One way to reproduce it is to call `GC.Collect()` right after `outputOptions.SetOutputHandler(handler.BeginImage, handler.WriteData);`  (https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Graphics/DxtBitmapContent.cs#L176).

_How to: Marshal Callbacks and Delegates By Using C++ Interop_
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/367eeye0.aspx

data.title: Fix SoundEffect disposal test to not use internal constructor
data.body:
XNA tests didn't compile because an internal SoundEffectInstance constructor was used in the InstanceNotDisposed test. This test was also not run because it was missing the "Test" attribute. 

After adding it in, the test ran fine in XNA but failed in MG because when Game is disposed the master voice is also disposed and you don't have access to the subvoices after that. I don't think XNA disposes of the master voice when game is disposed because trying to use a SFX after disposing game will work in XNA. The 'fix' in the first commit here is crap, because it doesn't solve anything, but I only just realised that :p 

I think Game really shouln't be involved in this to keep things nicely separated. It would be nice if you could run Audio through MG without creating a Game (just using MG as an audio wrapper). So I'd like to expose functions to setup audio (automatically done when creating a game) and dispose of all audio (not called by game) so the user has more control and game disposal doesn't kill all audio (compliant with XNA behaviour). Thoughts?

data.title: Add Localization  Content Processors and Methods to MG
data.body:
XNA had a sample for dealing with localised assets [1]. I think it might be a  good idea to add these as default processors to the MG content Pipeline so they are just built in.

So Im proposing we add the  `LocalizedFontDescription` and `LocalizedFontProcessor` code from the sample and then add a new method to the contentManager

`T LoadLocalized<T>(string assetName)`

People can then have the choice of loading using the standard Load method or using the other if that asset has a localized version.

[1] http://xbox.create.msdn.com/en-US/education/catalog/sample/localization

data.title: Content Statistics
data.body:
It would be very useful for the `MGCB` tool to gather content statistics.  The statistics would be generated when content building occurs and would be persisted to an XML file.

Example of statistics we could gather would be:
- Number of models in the project.
- MBs of compressed `SoundEffect` s.
- Percentage of uncompressed vs compressed `Texture2D`s.
- The disk space required for all content.
- The approximate memory usage in game of all content.
- The amount of textures in a particular folder.

These statistics then could be parsed and presented in the Pipeline tool UI in some useful manner.

Ideally most of the information could be gathered from the builder without the help of individual processors.  Types of content, what folders they exist in, number of files, disk space required, etc can be all gathered from the outside.  Things like if the content is compressed or not or the runtime memory usage would require either some cooperation from the processor to work efficiently.  We could easily add additional methods to the `ContentProcessorContext` or the base `ContentItem` to help record the necessary information.

This feature would make diagnosing content size issues easier and more accurate than the guessing and runtime measurements we have to do now.

data.title: Add a null reference check on DisplayMode for #5040
data.body:
There's currently a fix for #5040 in the form of adjusting templates, however this only assists developers creating new projects going forward.  For existing developers, they need to add or create an `app.manifest` file in their project.

We wasted about 6 hours remotely debugging this issue before we realised it was that Windows 10 configures a 125% DPI by default, and that on this particular machine that setting hadn't been changed to be 100%.  We then found #5040 which then documented the issue.

This adds a null check in `DEBUG` builds so that if DisplayMode is null, the developer gets a much more useful exception around the potential issue that might be occurring.

data.title: [WinDX] Opening Steam overlay results in "stuck" keys

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I'm currently working on Steam integration with my game and I came across an issue when opening the Steam overlay. The Shift and Tab keys (which you press to open the overlay) end up getting "stuck" in the game. I'm assuming this is because the Steam overlay intercepts all the key events, so MonoGame never sees the "release" events for these keys.

I'm having this problem with the WinDX build, but I imagine it also affects other desktop builds. (UPDATE: This actually seems to only affect MonoGame DirectX. Both XNA and MonoGame SDL2 work correctly.)

My current workaround to this issue is to clear MonoGame's internal key buffer (i.e. `Keyboard._keys`) whenever the Steam overlay is opened or closed. However given this is not publicly exposed, the only way to do this is by changing MonoGame to expose it or by using reflection. I am not sure if this is the best way of dealing with this, but it seems to work well.

Has anyone else experienced this particular problem? And if so, how did you solve it?

And if my workaround seems reasonable, would it be acceptable to add this to the MonoGame API (e.g. a `Keyboard.Flush` method which clears the buffer)? If so, I'm more than happy to submit a PR.

data.title: Improve Texture.GetData and SetData parameter validation
data.body:
This fixes the issues mentioned in #5119 and fixes #1455. Only Texture2D is thoroughly tested for now. I also implemented TextureCube.GetData overloads that were missing.

Something that not everyone might agree with is I changed back the validation of elementCount as it was in XNA. We changed this so that when elementCount >= data.Width \* data.Height the functions worked, while in XNA they check elementCount == data.Width \* data.Height. I changed this back because I think this is ambiguous. You could argue we're more flexible than XNA if we allow elementCount to be larger, but in fact elementCount itself is not used, so allowing arbitrary values might confuse the user. 

The fact that elementCount is even in there is a bit weird in the API... It's really only used for validation. Maybe when we start moving away from XNA we can break this by removing it and make it optional for a while (default value of 0 and remove the check) to ease the transition. Or just overload and obsolete the old calls. IMO it makes a lot more sense to have `GetData<T>(T[] data)`, `GetData<T>(Rectangle rect, T[] data)`, `GetData<T>(Rectangle rect, T[] data, int startIndex)` and overloads as needed for mip level, arraySlice etc.

Just a quick snippet that points out why I think elementCount is misplaced (named params for your convenience):

```
var tex = new Texture2D(graphicsDevice: gd, width: 20, height: 1);
var buffer = new Color[10];
tex.GetData(data: buffer, startIndex: 0, elementCount: 10);
```

This fails in XNA (and MG) with 

```
System.ArgumentException : The size of the data passed in is too large or too small for this resource.
```

Fixes #5172 
Fixes #4276

data.title: MGFX preprocessor doesn't like backslash in #includes
data.body:
If you use a relative path in an FX file include like this:

```
#include "..\platform.fxh"
```

The current preprocessor will pass `..platform.fxh` to the `MGFile.getChildFile(string name)`.

This seems to be a bug in the preprocessor library that needs to be fixed.

For now the workaround is to flip the slash:

```
#include "../platform.fxh"
```

Which the preprocessor handles fine.
